questions.text: Inquest by Judicial Magistrate is compulsory in case of
questions.solution:
Executive Magistrate inquest is done in cases of

  1. Suicide/Suspicious death of a woman within 7 years of marriage
  2. Exhumation
  3. Death caused/suspected to be caused by police

Inquest by Judicial Magistrate is compulsory in cases of

  1. Death of a person or
  2. Disappearance of a person or
  3. Rape in Police custody or in any other custody authorized by the Magistrate/Court such as Jail, remand home, Borstal school, psychiatric hospital etc.

questions.text: Mr. 'A' killed Mr. 'B' in a park. Mr. 'C' came to the court of Law as prosecution witness saying "I saw Mr. 'A' with the knife minutes before the incident". The evidence given by Mr. 'C' helps in the court to prove the crime as In case of Cafe coronary, the cause of death is
questions.solution:
Types of evidence:

  1. Documentary: It includes all documents produced for the inspection of the Court.
  2. Oral:
    1. Direct: Evidence of a fact which is actually in issue, e.g., an electric blanket that has caused injury, prescription, or a consent form.
    2. Indirect or Circumstantial : It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder. Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical or reasonable inferences from the information presented.
    3. Hearsay: It is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, or evidence he obtained from a third party, which is presented in the Court in order to assert that the facts contained in the statement are true, e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. In such case direct evidence can be given only by B that he had seen C committing a crime.

questions.text: The defence witness in a murder trial is cross-examined by
questions.solution: • In the case of cross examination, the witness is questioned by the lawyer for the opposite party. For a defence witness, the opposite lawyer is the public prosecutor, and he will conduct cross examination.

questions.text: While recording evidence in a court of law, the lawyer asked the witness - "Did you see that Mr. 'A' killed Mr. 'B'?". Witness answered - "Yes". This type of question is permitted in
questions.solution:
• The leading question is the one, which suggests its own answer, where answer can be given in the form of 'yes' or 'no'.
  • Leading questions are not to be asked during recording of evidence during Examination-in-Chief aka, chief examination or direct examination) and Re-examination, unless the witness becomes hostile.
  • Leading questions are not to be asked while recording dying declaration also.

questions.text: During hysterectomy surgery, there was damage to the ureter. This is covered under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
• Res ipsa loquitur: Means, the things speak for itself. E.g., a) Operation on wrong patient/limb/eye/organ. b) Keeping a surgical instrument/swab in the body cavity after operation. c) Prescription of an overdose etc.
    • In this scenario, the doctor is not supposed to injure the ureter during hysterectomy. If the doctor injures the ureter he is guilty of medical negligence under the doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur.
  • Medical maloccurence: Despite of proper treatment (Absolutely no negligence from the doctor), the patient has not responded for treatment.
  • Novus actus intervenience = New Act Intervening. That means, events to be taken place has been intervened by an unforeseen, unexpected new event.
  • Misadventure: An unfortunate incident; a mishap; an inadvertent act. E.g., Pt. dies of anaphylactic shock for the test dose itself. It may be during the treatment (therapeutic misadventure), or during diagnosis diagnostic misadventure), or during experiment (experimentalmmisadventure).

questions.text: Law does not consider the following doctrine in a charge of criminal negligence
questions.solution: • The doctor can take the defence of contributory negligence only in civil cases (civil suits) when the patient or his relatives sue the doctor for damages. Not in criminal negligence.

questions.text: 'Respondeat superior' pertains to
questions.solution: • Vicarious liability is a legal doctrine that assigns liability for an injury to a person who did not cause the injury but who has a legal relationship to the person who did act negligently. It is also referred to as imputed negligence. Legal relationships that can lead to imputed negligence include the relationship between parent and child, husband and wife, owner of a vehicle and driver, and employer and employee. As per the doctrine of Respondeat superior (Latin=Let the master answer), it is the duty of the hospital (employer) to pay the damages to the patient for the damage caused by hospital employee.

questions.text: Which of the following is the disciplinary action for 'Professional Misconduct'?
questions.solution:
• If the doctor is found guilty of professional misconduct, disciplinary actions taken by SMC/NMC are:
  • Warning notice is a code of conduct issued by NMC or SMC, containing certain practices which are regarded as falling within the meaning of the term "Professional Misconduct", which is issued to all the doctors at the time of registration. It is not a disciplinary action.
    1. Warning
    2. Monetary penalty, and
    3. Penal erasure (i.e., removal of the name from the medical register).
  • Penal erasure can be temporary or permanent. Permanent penal erasure is known as Professional death sentence.

questions.text: As per MCI rules, if any request is made for medical records, the documents shall be issued within the period of
questions.solution:
As per National Medical Commission (Professional conduct, etiquette and ethics/regulations, 2002 amendment),

  • Indoor patients records should be kept for - 3 years.
  • A doctor should provide the medical records within 5 days when the patient or his/her authorised representative makes a request for it.

questions.text: A police officer found a dead male child in the streets, brought the child to the forensic department. The findings of the child were as below. "Weight 1000g., foot length 8cm, thick nails, eyelids opened, pupillary membrane disappeared, testis is in external inguinal ring, crown rump length 23cm". Based on the above findings, the age of the baby is:
questions.solution:
Estimation of gestational age by crown-heel length (CHL)

  • Rule of Haase: If CHL is <25cm, gestational age in lunar months is equal to √ of CHL.
  • Morrison's rule: If CHL is >25cm, gestational age in lunar months is equal to CHL/5.
  • Crown rump length (CRL) ≈ 2/3rd of CHL or CHL ≈ 1.5 x CRL.

Here, CHL = 23 x 1.5 = 34.5; Rounded off to 35; Gestational age = 35/5 = 7 months

questions.text: The fingerprints formation completes at
questions.solution: • The fingerprints develop at 12-16 weeks of I.U.L. and the formation is completed by 24 weeks of I.U.L.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child will have
questions.solution:
Formula for calculation of Number of permanent and temporary teeth:

  • Permanent teeth = (Age - 5) x 4
  • Temporary teeth = 24 - Permanent teeth

E.g., In a 10-year-old child:

  • Permanent teeth = (10 - 5) x 4 = 20
  • Temporary teeth = 24 - 20 = 4

questions.text: The maximum age of the person by the analysis of carpal bones in this X-ray is
questions.solution:
• In the above X-ray image of the wrist in the question, all the carpal bones except pisiform are seen.
  • Pisifor appears at the age of 9-12 years.
  • Scaphoid, trapezium and traphezoid have appeared, which appears at 4-5 years.
  • Hence the age of the child is between 4 and 12 years.
  • The maximum age can be 10 years (As per the options given)

questions.text: If the cause of death is unknown even after detailed examination and investigations, it is known as
questions.solution:
• Negative Autopsy (2-5%): Absolutely no findings after external and internal examination, HPE and chemical analysis. Opinion as to the cause of death cannot be given. It is due to functional failure of a vital tissue/organ. E.g., Death due to vagal inhibition, laryngeal spasm etc.
  • Obscure Autopsy: There are minimum findings (not clear cut), but cannot correlate with the cause of death after external & internal examination, HPE & chemical analysis. Opinion as to the cause of death cannot be given.

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxia death due to neck compression is
questions.solution:
• "Y" shaped incision: Starts from both the mastoid to reach the sternal notch & further extending to reach the symphysis pubis, avoiding the umbilicus. Done in neck injuries and asphyxial deaths by compression over the neck.
  • Modified 'Y' shaped incision: Incision extends from both the acromion, running away & below the breast to reach xiphisternum and then extending to symphysis pubis, avoiding the umbilicus. Done in females for cosmetic purpose.

questions.text: 'En bloc' removal at autopsy is called
questions.solution:
• Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs are removed as a sigle large organ block (En masse/En bloc)
  • Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.
  • Ghon's technique: Block by block dissection - Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital systems are removed as separate organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: In situ dissection.

questions.text: A patient of multi drug resistant TB dies of respiratory failure due to lobar pneumonia. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for line 1a of death certificate?
questions.solution:
Immediate cause → Ia

  • State the disease, injury or complication which caused death
  • Not the mode of dying such as heart failure, asthenia, etc.

Antecedent cause → Ib/ Ib and Ic/Ib, Ic and Id etc.

  • Ib → The condition given rise to immediate cause (Ia)
  • Ic → The condition given rise to Ib
  • Id → The condition given rise to Ic etc.

Other significant conditions → II

  • Contributing to the death but not related to the disease or conditions causing it

choices.text: Eyelid, face, neck and jaw, upper limb
Eyelid, face, neck and jaw, thorax
Eyelid, Neck and jaw, face, thorax
Eyelid, neck and jaw, face, upper limb

questions.text: Correct sequence of rigor mortis is
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis first occurs in heart (overall); Externally - upper eyelid.

  • Rigor mortis follows Nysten's law, i.e., proximodistal progression. The order of Rigor mortis is
    • Eyelids, neck & lower jaw, face, chest, upper limbs, abdomen, lower limbs & fingers & toes.

choices.text: Seen only when the eyes remain open after death
Due to deposition of foreign bodies and cellular debris
Seen due to phenomenon of trucking

questions.text: Not true regarding the condition shown in the image
questions.solution:
Tache noir de la sclerotique:

  • After death if eyelids remain opened there will be formation of cell debris + deposition of foreign bodies as triangular patches on sclera at each side of cornea in 3-4 hrs. initially yellow, then dark brown and later black.
  • Railroad phenomenon which occurs in the retinal arteries due to segmentation of blood cells is known as trucking.

choices.text: It's due to compression of capillaries
It disappears along with the onset of putrefaction

questions.text: True for 'areas of contact flattening' is/are
questions.solution:
Hypostasis/PM/lividity/Suggilation/PM Staining/lucidity/cogitation/livor mortis.

  • It is bluish red/bluish purple discoloration after death on dependent parts of the body.
  • Due to gravity shifting & collecting & blood in capillaries & small veins in superficial layer of dermis.
  • Doesn't appear on areas of contact flattening (pressure areas) due to compression of capillaries.
  • It disappears along with the onset of putrefaction.
  • If a body is left undisturbed, the postmortem staining persists till it merges with discoloration of putrefaction.

questions.text: Identify the finding in image
questions.solution:
Marbling:

  • It is due to staining of walls of superficial veins by sulphmethaemoglobin (Initially red, then greenish).
  • Commences in about 24 hrs, becomes prominent in 36-48 hrs.
  • Seen most clearly on the thighs, sides of the abdomen and chest & shoulders.

questions.text: Bullet finger printings are
questions.solution:
Bullet markings:

  1. Primary/class characteristics:
    1. They are due to rifling (Impression of lands).
    2. It is a macroscopic finding.
    3. Specific to the model of the gun.
  2. Secondary/Individual characteristics (Bullet fingerprinting):
    1. Due to irregularities on surface of lands.
    2. It is microscopic finding.
    3. Specific to the individual gun.

questions.text: The following is victim of firearm injury. What is the suspected range of the shot?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the wound of entry surrounded with tattooing. There is no blackening.
  • Appearance of wounds in various ranges in rifled firearms:
    1. Firm contact: Wound of entry + Muzzle impression.
    2. Loose contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening (corona) + Burning & singeing (Muzzle impression is unlikely)
    3. Angled contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Partial muzzle impression + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.
    4. Close shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.
    5. Near shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening + Tattooing.
    6. Intermediate shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Tattooing.
    7. Distant shot; Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar.

questions.text: Bevelling of inner table of skull suggests
questions.solution:
• The entry and exit wound in skull can be differentiated from looking at the wound margins, whether the margins are clean cut or bevelled (crater formation).
  • In the skull, the wound of entrance shows a punched-in (clean) hole in the outer table. The inner table is unsupported, and a cone-shaped piece of bone is detached forming a crater that is larger than the hole on the outer table and shows bevelling (sloping surface).
  • Meantime, at the wound of exit, the inner table shows a punched-in (clean) hole and as the outer table is unsupported, and a cone-shaped piece of bone is detached forming a crater that is larger than the hole on the inner table and shows bevelling (sloping surface).

questions.text: The type of stab wound caused by a knife over the thigh is known as
questions.solution:
• The stab wounds are classified as -
    1. Incised Punctured,
    2. Lacerated Punctured,
    3. Incised Penetrating,
    4. Lacerated Penetrating,
    5. Incised Perforating and
    6. Lacerated Perforating.
  • Punctured means stab has entered into the soft tissue, but not into a cavity.
  • Penetrating means stab has entered into a cavity and Perforating means, the stab is associated with wound of entry and exit (through and through).
  • Incised or lacerated, depends on the type of the pointed weapon - whether it is caused by a sharp pointed weapon or a blunt pointed weapon respectively.

questions.text: The picture depicts
questions.solution:
Pressure Abrasions (crushing or friction abrasions):

  • Pressure abrasion is caused by sustained pressure.
  • The ligature mark in cases of hanging and strangulation and the teeth bite marks are the examples.

Impact Abrasions (contact or imprint abrasions):

  • Imprint abrasion is caused by momentary impact.
  • When a person is knocked down by a motor car, the pattern of the radiator grille, a headlamp rim or the tread of the tyre may be seen on the skin.

Patterned abrasions:

  • Whether it is imprint abrasion or pressure abrasion, if it gives rise to a pattern of the causative object, then it is known as patterned abrasion and patterned abrasion is the Best term to use.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury
questions.solution:
• In the given image, the margins are regular, and the edges are bruised/contused
  • Lacerated wound: Margins are irregular, and edges are bruised/contused
  • Incised wound: Margins are regular, and edges are not bruised/contused
  • Chop wound: Margins are regular, and edges are bruised/contused

questions.text: Sweating is absent in
questions.solution:
• In Heat stroke (Heat hyperpyrexia), body temperature increases above the level of 40.5°C. The skin is dry, hot and flushed with completw absence of sweating.
  • Heat cramps (Miner's / Stoker's/Fireman's cramps) is caused by rapid dehydration of body through the loss of water and salt in the sweat. Muscle cramp is due to loss of Na+ ion. There is no increase in body temperature.
  • Heat prostration (Heat exhaustion/Heat syncope/Heat collapse) is due to peripheral vascular collapse. There is no increase in body temperature.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution:
Self-inflicted and fabricated wounds:

  • Self-inflicted wounds are those inflicted by a person on his own body. Fabricated wounds (fictitious, forged or invented wounds) are those which may be produced by a person on his own body(self-inflicted) or by another with his consent.
  • Fabricated wounds are mostly incised wounds.

Hesitation marks or tentative cuts or trial wounds:

  • They are cuts which are multiple, small, and superficial often involving only the skin and are seen at the beginning of the main incised wound.
  • They are self-inflicted wounds made while attempting to commit suicide.
  • They are usually on the radial side of the forearm and wrist (cut wrist injuries) or in the neck 9cut throat injuries)

choices.text: Seat belt mark over left shoulder
Sparrow feet marks on the face

questions.text: In car accident, driver and front passenger both died. All the following in post-mortem examination will help to identify the driver except
questions.solution:
• Seat belt mark over left shoulder clearly indicates that he was not the driver (in India).
  • Sparrow feet marks on the face indicates that the victim could be either driver or front seat passenger (As both have equal chances)
  • Whiplash injury to spinal cord may be seen in both driver and passengers (but less common in driver as he will be alert at the time of impact and stabilises his neck)
  • Steering wheel impact indicates he is the driver

choices.text: Seen on opposite side of area of impact
Most common site is frontal & temporal lobes
Fall on temporal area may produce contrecoup injury on ipsilateral lobe
Fall on frontal area produce contrecoup injury on occipital lobe

questions.text: False statement in contre coup injuries is
questions.solution:
• Coup injury is the injury sustained at the site of impact which is seen in case of stationary head.
  • Countercoup injury is the injury sustained on the side opposite to the site of impact which is seen in case of movable head.
  • Intermediary coup injury is seen in between coup & counter coup injury/
  • Counter coup is most common in temporal & frontal areas and is almost unknown in occipital area.
  • Counter coup injuries are rare before the age of 3 years.
  • Fall on temporal area may produce counter coup injury on ipsilateral lobe by hitting against the falx cerebri.

questions.text: A 23-year male patient was brought to the hospital with history of stove burst. Burns involving face & head with singeing of hair, neck, both arms and front of chest bilaterally noted. The percentage of burns is
questions.solution:
• In adults. body surface area (BSA) burn is calculated by Wallace rule (Rule of nine)
  • Head + Neck = 7+2= 9, Arm + Forearm + Hand = 4+3+2= 9, Thigh + Leg + Foot = 10+5+3= 18, Front of the trunk = 18%, Back of the trunk = 18%, and Perinium = 1%
  • In this case, face & head with singeing of hair, neck, both arms and front of chest bilaterally noted.
    • Head (which includes face) = 7
    • Neck = 2
    • Both arms = 4+4 = 8
    • Front of chest bilaterally = 9
    • Total BSA = 7+2+8+9 = 26

choices.text: Singeing of hairs over face and eyebrow

questions.text: A patient came with a history of burns in the household to the ER, She was conscious and admitted in the ICU. Even after efficient management she succumbed within 6 hours. Clinical feature suggestive of inhalational injury are all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Inhalational burns may cause:

  1. Hypoxia - as the flame utilizes the available oxygen.
  2. Hoarseness of voice and stridor- as the hot air injuries the laryngeal mucosa.
  3. Soot deposition in air passage - due to flying ashes.
  4. Yellow sputum - as the oxides of nitrogen converts the sputum into yellow.

Note: Singeing of hairs can take place only by the actual contact with the flame

choices.text: Seen in all cases of lightening

questions.text: True about the picture shown below
questions.solution:
• Filigree burns (Lichtenberg/ arborescent marks, feathering, ferning, keraunographic burns)
    • Most common site is shoulder, front of chest, flanks.
    • It is seen in 20-33% of cases.
    • It does not follow vascular channels; it is due to lysis of RBCs along the path of electric current.
    • It disappears in about 1-2 days.
    • It is pink to brownish in colour.

questions.text: Spanish windlass technique, is also known as/a type of
questions.solution:
Spanish windlass technique

  • It was a method of judicial execution in Spain & Turkey
  • A metal collar around the neck was tightened by a lever from behind
  • It's a method of garrotting (Although not as per definition)

questions.text: A person is brought dead to the mortuary. History revealed that he collapsed while having dinner. On examination, there was cyanosis, petechial hemorrhages and a bolus of food in the larynx. Blood alcohol level was 120mg%. The probable cause of death is
questions.solution:
• In case of 'Cafe coronary' The victim may be observed slumping over the dining table or collapsing suddenly while walking across the room after having meals, with no signs of respiratory distress or any of the 'classic signs of asphyxia'.
  • However, autopsy usually reveals a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx. Many cases have been reported where the victim was merely seen dead while sitting or just after sitting in a chair, the mode of death probably being cardiac arrest due to overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system through the stimulation of branches of vagus nerve supplying the laryngeal and/or pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Fairly high level of alcohol has been found in most cases of cafe coronary deaths. The suppression of gag reflex due to alcohol or drugs makes the individual susceptible to this calamity.

In this given scenario, there are asphyxial signs in the form of cyanosis and petechial haemorrhages. So, the cause of death is choking.

questions.text: Not associated with saltwater drowning is
questions.solution:
There are 2 types of drowning

  1. Fresh water drowning:
    1. Water from lungs enters blood (due to osmosis) → Hemodilution → Hemolysis → Release of K+ → Hyperkalemia → Ventricular fibrillation → Death in about 4-5 minutes
  2. Saltwater drowning:
    1. Water from blood enters lungs (due to osmosis) → Hemoconcentration → Hypernatremia → Bradycardia → Cardiac arrest → Death in about 8-12 minutes

questions.text: A vaginal swab from a victim of rape should be taken within ___ days to detect spermatozoa
questions.solution: • A vaginal swab from a victim of rape should be taken within 3 days to detect spermatozoa and within 4 days to detect semen.

questions.text: Child who is passive agent of sodomy is known as
questions.solution:
• Sodomy is anal intercourse between two males or between a male and female.
  • It is called gerontophilia when the passive agent is an adult and paederasty, when the passive agent is a young boy, who is known as catamite.
  • A paedophile is an adult who repeatedly engages in sexual activities with children below the age of puberty.

choices.text: He is criminally responsible for his act
He is partially responsible for his act
Have diminished responsible for his act

questions.text: In case of Kleptomania
questions.solution:
• 84 IPC (Now, Sec. 22 of BNS) deals with criminal responsibilities of a mentally ill person
  • According to this, criteria for not to be liable are
    1. There should be unsoundness of mind
    2. Should not know the nature of the act, or
    3. Should not know that, whether it is right or wrong.
  • In the case of kleptomania, he knows very well that what is he doing and he also knows that what is he doing is wrong. So, he is liable under Sec. 22 of BNS.

choices.text: Coagulation necrosis occurs at the site of burn

questions.text: A man throws sulfuric acid on the face of his wife after a fight following which she comes to the emergency for supportive management. All these statements are true about chemical burns EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• In case of corrosive burns, there will be No singeing, No red line and No blisters (except in formic acid)
  • Sulphuric acid cause lcerated patches and coagulation necrosis at the site of burn

questions.text: All the following are associated with burns of hydrofluoric acid EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Hydrofluoric acid (HF) Causes

  • Severe throbbing pain
  • Tissue necrosis and destruction
  • Acidosis
  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalaemia

choices.text: Reported in all cases of OP poisoning

questions.text: Which of the following characterizes the intermediate syndrome in OP poisoning?
questions.solution:
Intermediate Syndrome:

  • In some cases of OP poisoning after one to four days muscle weakness and paralysis characterized by motor cranial nerve palsies, weakness of neck flexor and proximal limb muscles, and acute respiratory paresis are seen due to prolonged cholinesterase inhibition and muscle necrosis. It does not respond to oximes or atropine.

Delayed Syndrome (Now called Delayed encephalopathy and neuropathy syndrome):

  • It sometimes occurs 1-4 weeks after poisoning due to nerve demyelination and is characterised by flaccid weakness and atrophy of distal limb muscles, or spasticity and ataxia. It rapidly progresses to a flaccid paresis which can ascend similar to Guillain-Barre syndrome. Reflexes are diminished. The disease may progress for 2 to 3 months, and muscle wasting occurs.

questions.text: In a case of lead poisoning, the enzymes inhibited are
questions.solution:
• Pb inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of ALA dehydratase.
  • It also inhibits ferrochelatase.
  • Chronic lead poisoning manifests with initial polycythemia, later anemia, reticulocytosis, poikilocytosis, anisocytosis, Cabot's ring (Inclusion body in RBCs), and Basophilic stippling (Punctate basophilia)
  • Basophilic stippling is due to the inhibition of pyrimidine-5 nucleotidase
  • Eosinophilia is more consistent finding than punctate basophilia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old pesticide manufacturing factory worker has presented the casualty with the findings. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: The image shows a condition called Black foot disease which is seen in case of chronic arsenic poisoning. It is nothing but gangrenous change due to peripheral vascular spasm.

questions.text: Effective treatment for Minamata disease is
questions.solution:
Treatment for mercury poisoning:

  • Drug of choice is BAL
  • BAL + penicillamine is a contraindication because it forms a toxic compound
  • EDTA is also contraindicated as it is nephrotoxic.
  • No chelator for methyl mercury or ethyl mercury is approved by the FDA; DMSA is most frequently used for severe methyl mercury poisoning.
  • (Minamata disease was caused by methyl mercury)

choices.text: ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Neostigmine and ventilatory support may be given along with ASV in cobra bite
Indian polyvalent ASV is not effective against hump nosed viper
ASV + neostigmine + atropine indicated for treatment of krait bite

questions.text: False statement regarding snake bite?
questions.solution:
Hospital treatment for snakebite:

  • Wait and watch for signs & symptoms.
  • If indicated → Begin PASV (Polyvalent anti snake venom) with 10 vials.
  • PASV is effective against
    1. Common cobra,
    2. Common krait,
    3. Russel's viper, and
    4. Saw scaled viper
  • PASV produced by Hoffkine biopharmaceutical company neutralises venom of pit viper due to para-specific activity.

Fixation of toxins:

  • Common cobra → neurotoxins get fixed at post synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has a role.
  • Common krait → neurotoxins get fixed at pre-synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has no role.

choices.text: Formic acid is mainly responsible for toxicity

questions.text: False about methanol poisoning
questions.solution:
Methanol

  • Toxic effects are due to formic acid.
  • Earliest symptom - severe abdominal pain
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Visual defects - Snow field vision, constricted visual field, optic neuritis → temporary blindness and optic atrophy → permanent blindness
  • Fatal dose → 60-200ml
  • Antidote for both methyl alcohol and ethylene glycol 4-methyl pyrazole (Fomepizole) and ethanol.
  • Both 4-methyl pyrazole and ethanol acts by competitive inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A person was admitted to the hospital with tachycardia, tachypnoea, increased BP, and scratch marks on the body. Diagnosis is poisoning by
questions.solution:
• Cocaine causes excited delirium which causes - tachycardia, tachypnoea, hypertension, hyperthermia, agitation and incoordination.
  • Cocaine also causes tactile hallucination - known as Magnan's symptom/coke bugs/cocaine bugs (reason for scratch marks on the body)

questions.text: Acrodynia is associated with which poison?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia or Pink/Swift's/Selter's/Feer's disease:

  • Seen in case of poisoning by mercurial compounds.
  • It is painful, parasthetic, peeling, perspiring, pink & puffy hands and feet in children.
